Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Self-powered Dual-mode Piezoelectric Resonant Pressure/Temperature Sensors for Oil and Gas Field Explorations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) Collaborative Research project is to investigate a novel self-powered dual-mode piezoelectric resonant pressure/temperature sensor that can operate in the harsh downhole environments without requiring external electricity as a step to resolve the critical challenges for downhole sensing and power supply posed by high temperature, high pressure, large shock environment of oil/gas field explorations. The material properties of the new high temperature piezoelectric material will be characterized, and theoretical analysis will be performed to predict the specific cut angle for dual-mode sensing. A novel torsional vibration energy harvester and thermoelectric generator will be designed to harness electricity from downhole drilling with dual function of suppressing the self-excited torsional vibration of the drill string. The complete self-powered sensing system will be validated through laboratory and in-field test.

If successful, the results will create new knowledge on high temperature and high pressure sensing and energy harvesting. The data of material properties and theoretical modeling will not only enable predictable design of the piezoelectric resonant sensor operating in harsh environments but also will lay a solid foundation for future piezoelectric resonator design. The proposed multi-source thermoelectric and electromagnetic energy harvesting mechanism not only generates useful energy from the intrinsic downhole heat and drillstring vibrations, but also creates new knowledge of energy harvesting in harsh environments with broader applications. The self-powered sensing system will lead the way to drilling deeper and more productive oil & gas wells to meet the urgent national energy need. Integrated with the research is a carefully orchestrated educational and outreach plan at the both participating universities, particularly for minorities, women, undergraduate, and K12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcome report

PI: Prof. Haifeng Zhang, Department of Mechanical and Energy Engineering, University of North Texas

The goal of this GOALI proposal is to resolve through university-industry collaboration the most challenging sensing problem facing the oil and gas industry: downhole sensing and power in high temperature, high pressure, and large shock environments. As a step towards this goal, two university PIs are collaborating with world-renowned scientists from Schlumberger, the world's leading oilfield services company, to investigate a novel self-powered dual-mode piezoelectric resonant pressure/temperature sensor that could operate in the harsh downhole environment without requiring external electricity.

Traditionally, downhole pressure sensor needs additional temperature sensor to compensate the temperature–induced frequency shit which will affect the pressure sensor measurement. This additional temperature sensor increase the cost and caused additional measurement error due to temperature gradient. Thus, we propose a dual mode pressure/temperature sensor that can measure both pressure and temperature simultaneously with a single sensor element. Such kind of sensor will make the pressure measurement more accurate with much low cost.

To predict the proposed dual mode sensing behavior, we have performed intense theoretical modelling to find out the specific material orientation. A few such material orientations have been discovered and then we have fabricated such sensor element and a series of experimental tests have been performed to validate the predicted dual mode sensing behavior. The experiment tests include the temperature/force frequency measurement for two frequencies associated with two vibration modes. The result is consistent with the theoretical result, which verified the feasibility of using this new piezoelectric crystal as a dual mode sensing element.

We have also investigated another approach to enable the dual mode sensing behavior. We use a typtical crystal with normal material orientation as the sensing element and use beat frequency to measure the temperature and use another frequency to measure the force. This method has simplified the sensor fabrication process and still could measure force and temperature at the same time.

Along the way of this important discovery, we have designed a novel motor-drive loading device to automatically measure the force frequency effect of langasite resonator. The device we designed has high force resolution and accuracy, which has the potential for commercial application to characterize small force sensor.

We have theoretically computed temperature-induced frequency shifts for quartz surface acoustic wave (SAW) temperature sensor, in which, a variety of SAW wave propagation direction/cut angle have been discovered which could be used to improve the sensitivity of SAW temperature sensor.

We have also systematically measured the second-order elastic constants of piezoelectric single crystals based on ultrasound method. The results are consistent with previous peer’s measurement result.

Our findings have opened up a new dual mode pressure/temperature sensor that could operate in high temperature harsh environment. Upon successful fabrication of this type of sensor, many industry segments such as oil and gas industry, nuclear engineering, chemical engineering, aerospace engineering and geothermal engineering will benefit from it. As in these industry, very few commercial sensors that could operate in harsh environment are available. A robust and durable harsh environment sensor will propel the instrumentation and control for these industry segments to a new level.

This research project has created several education opportunities as well. Through this project, the PI has cultivated two graduate students, a few undergraduate students and high school students. Two international students from Vietnam and Mexico has gained experience on piezoelectric device through internship in the PI’s group. The PI has also integrated the project content into the courses he has taught so that more undergraduate students could learn knowledge on sensor design. He has disseminate the research findings to the public through many seminars and conference presentations.
